abstract: Banks, facing an interest rate conundrum, are wary of depleting their cash reserves.
snippet: Banks, facing an interest rate conundrum, are wary of depleting their cash reserves.
lead_paragraph: The big gap between short- and long-term interest rates should mean fat lending profits for American banks. But some, like Wells Fargo, are wary of rising interest rates. Higher rates overall might encourage them to lend, but simultaneously could reduce their capacity to do so. It’s a tricky problem.

byline.original: By Rolfe Winkler and Richard Beales

abstract: A unit of Warren E. Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway, General Re, has agreed to pay $92.2 million to settle accusations that it helped the American International Group and Prudential Financial manipulate financial statements, the federal government said Wednesday.
snippet: A unit of Warren E. Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway, General Re, has agreed to pay $92.2 million to settle accusations that it helped the American International Group and Prudential Financial manipulate financial statements, the federal government sa...
lead_paragraph: A unit of Warren E. Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway, General Re, has agreed to pay $92.2 million to settle accusations that it helped the American International Group and Prudential Financial manipulate financial statements, the federal government said Wednesday.

headline.main: GenRe Settles With U.S. Over A.I.G. and Prudential

abstract: The 2010 U.S. market for initial public offerings opens this week with a company connected to famed investor Warren E. Buffett, the life insurer Symetra Financial, getting most of the attention.
snippet: The 2010 U.S. market for initial public offerings opens this week with a company connected to famed investor Warren E. Buffett, the life insurer Symetra Financial, getting most of the attention.
lead_paragraph: The 2010 U.S. market for initial public offerings opens this week with a company connected to famed investor Warren E. Buffett getting most of the attention.

headline.main: Symetra Offering May Overshadow 5 Other I.P.O.’s

abstract: Irene B. Rosenfeld, chief of Kraft Foods, is taking a chance by going against Warren E. Buffett’s objections to the Cadbury deal, Reuters Breakingviews says.
snippet: Irene B. Rosenfeld, chief of Kraft Foods, is taking a chance by going against Warren E. Buffett’s objections to the Cadbury deal, Reuters Breakingviews says.
lead_paragraph: Irene Rosenfeld is clearly feeling lucky, Reuters Breakingviews says. Ms. Rosenfeld, the chief executive of Kraft Foods, raised her price to secure Cadbury’s agreement to a takeover. But in reducing the stock component, she also removed a chance of Warren E. Buffett voting against the deal, the publication notes.

abstract: Warren E. Buffett may have real doubts about Kraft Foods’ $19.3 billion takeover of Cadbury, but debt investors beg to differ.
snippet: Warren E. Buffett may have real doubts about Kraft Foods’ $19.3 billion takeover of Cadbury, but debt investors beg to differ.
lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett may have real doubts about Kraft Foods‘ $19.3 billion takeover of Cadbury, but debt investors apparently don’t.

headline.main: Kraft Bond Investors Disagree With Buffett

abstract: Warren E. Buffett may have expressed ire over not being able to vote down Kraft’s new takeover bid for Cadbury, but the Deal Professor shows that companies can easily organize their acquisitions to make sure their shareholders never get that chance.
snippet: Warren E. Buffett may have expressed ire over not being able to vote down Kraft’s new takeover bid for Cadbury, but the Deal Professor shows that companies can easily organize their acquisitions to make sure their shareholders never get that chanc...
lead_paragraph: Kraft has deliberately structured its final offer to acquire Cadbury so that it won’t need the approval of its shareholders. That act of shareholder disempowerment isn’t sitting well with Warren E. Buffett.
